H0.text: The whistle material to shake is what causes a whistle to produce a sound when air is blown into it.

H1.text: The air inside the whistle to vibrate is what causes a whistle to produce a sound when air is blown into it.

H2.text: The air being absorbed by the whistle causes a whistle to produce a sound when blowing air into it.

H3.text: The air in the whistle heats up and expands when blown, causing the whistle to produce a sound.

A4.text: The conversion of flow energy to sound comes from an interaction between a solid material and a fluid stream.

A5.text: A whistle is a musical instrument which produces sound from a stream of gas, most commonly air.

A6.text: Sound is a vibration that propagates as an acoustic wave through a transmission medium such as a gas, liquid or solid.

A7.text: Sound can propagate through a medium such as air, water and solids as longitudinal waves and also as a transverse wave in solids.
